1→# Gist Widget Builder
     2→
     3→A Next.js 16 application with Clerk authentication and Convex backend.
     4→
     5→## Setup Instructions
     6→
     7→### 1. Install Dependencies
     8→
     9→```bash
    10→bun install
    11→```
    12→
    13→### 2. Set Up Clerk Authentication
    14→
    15→1. Create a Clerk account at https://clerk.com
    16→2. Create a new application in the Clerk Dashboard
    17→3. Copy your API keys from the **API Keys** page
    18→
    19→### 3. Configure Environment Variables
    20→
    21→Create or update `.env.local` with your Clerk keys:
    22→
    23→```bash
    24→# Clerk Authentication
    25→NEXT_PUBLIC_CLERK_PUBLISHABLE_KEY=pk_test_...
    26→CLERK_SECRET_KEY=sk_test_...
    27→CLERK_DOMAIN=https://your-app.clerk.accounts.dev
    28→CLERK_JWT_ISSUER_DOMAIN=https://your-app.clerk.accounts.dev
    29→
    30→# Clerk Webhook (for automatic user sync)
    31→CLERK_WEBHOOK_SECRET=whsec_...
    32→
    33→# Convex (auto-generated by npx convex dev)
    34→CONVEX_DEPLOYMENT=dev:...
    35→NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL=https://....convex.cloud
    36→```
    37→
    38→**Note**: The `CLERK_JWT_ISSUER_DOMAIN` is required for Convex to validate Clerk JWT tokens. It should match your Clerk Frontend API URL (same as `CLERK_DOMAIN`). The `CLERK_WEBHOOK_SECRET` is required for automatic user synchronization. See the [Webhook Setup](#webhook-setup-optional-but-recommended) section below for configuration instructions.
    39→
    40→### 4. Set Convex Environment Variable
    41→
    42→**Important**: The `CLERK_JWT_ISSUER_DOMAIN` must also be configured in the Convex Dashboard:
    43→
    44→1. Go to [Convex Dashboard → Environment Variables](https://dashboard.convex.dev)
    45→2. Navigate to your project settings → Environment Variables
    46→3. Click "Add Environment Variable"
    47→4. Add:
    48→   - **Name**: `CLERK_JWT_ISSUER_DOMAIN`
    49→   - **Value**: `https://your-app.clerk.accounts.dev` (same as your `CLERK_DOMAIN`)
    50→5. Click "Save"
    51→
    52→This step is **required** for Clerk-Convex authentication to work properly.
    53→
    54→### 5. Initialize Convex Project
    55→
    56→Run the following command to create/link a Convex project:
    57→
    58→```bash
    59→npx convex dev
    60→```
    61→
    62→This will:
    63→- Create a Convex project (or link to existing one)
    64→- Generate Convex environment variables in `.env.local`
    65→- Deploy the database schema (users table)
    66→- Start the Convex development server
    67→- Watch for changes in the `convex/` directory
    68→
    69→### 6. Start the Next.js Development Server
    70→
    71→In a **separate terminal**, run:
    72→
    73→```bash
    74→bun dev
    75→```
    76→
    77→Your app will be available at [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000)
    78→
    79→## Project Structure
    80→
    81→```
    82→/app
    83→  /layout.tsx              # Root layout with ClerkProvider
    84→  /ConvexClientProvider.tsx # Client-side Convex provider with Clerk integration
    85→  /page.tsx                # Home page with sign in/up buttons
    86→  /dashboard
    87→    /page.tsx              # Protected dashboard page
    88→  /globals.css             # Tailwind + shadcn CSS variables
    89→
    90→/components
    91→  /ui                      # shadcn components (button, card, input, label, form)
    92→  /Header.tsx              # Header with Clerk authentication UI
    93→
    94→/convex
    95→  /schema.ts               # Database schema (users table)
    96→  /auth.config.ts          # Clerk authentication configuration
    97→  /users.ts                # User queries and helpers
    98→  /_generated              # Auto-generated types (created by Convex)
    99→
   100→/lib
   101→  /utils.ts                # Utility functions (cn helper)
   102→
   103→/middleware.ts             # Clerk authentication middleware (route protection)
   104→```
   105→
   106→## Features
   107→
   108→- **Authentication**: Clerk authentication with pre-built UI components
   109→- **Protected Routes**: Middleware-based route protection (automatic)
   110→- **Real-time Database**: Convex backend with type-safe queries
   111→- **User Management**: Automatic user sync from Clerk to Convex
   112→- **Admin Portal**: Role-based access control with dedicated admin interface
   113→- **shadcn/ui**: Beautiful, accessible UI components
   114→- **TypeScript**: Full type safety throughout the application
   115→- **Next.js 16 Compatible**: Works with latest Next.js async APIs
   116→
   117→## Authentication Flow
   118→
   119→1. **Sign Up**: Users click "Sign Up" button → Clerk modal opens → Create account
   120→2. **Sign In**: Users click "Sign In" button → Clerk modal opens → Authenticate
   121→3. **User Sync**: User data automatically synced to Convex database
   122→4. **Dashboard**: Protected route accessible only when authenticated
   123→5. **Sign Out**: Click UserButton (top right) → Sign out
   124→
   125→## Architecture
   126→
   127→```
   128→User → Clerk (Auth UI) → JWT Token → Next.js App → Convex Database
   129→              ↓                                         ↓
   130→    ClerkProvider → ConvexProviderWithClerk → Authenticated Queries
   131→```
   132→
   133→**Key Components:**
   134→- **Clerk**: Authentication provider (UI, sessions, JWTs)
   135→- **Convex**: Database backend (users table, queries)
   136→- **Middleware**: Automatic route protection (public vs protected)
   137→- **ConvexProviderWithClerk**: Connects Clerk auth with Convex queries
   138→
   139→## Tech Stack
   140→
   141→- **Next.js 16**: React framework with App Router and Turbopack
   142→- **React 19.2**: Latest React with modern hooks and patterns
   143→- **Clerk**: Authentication and user management platform
   144→- **Convex**: Backend-as-a-service with real-time database
   145→- **shadcn/ui**: Component library built on Radix UI
   146→- **Tailwind CSS**: Utility-first CSS framework
   147→- **TypeScript 5.9.3**: Type-safe development
   148→- **Bun 1.3.1**: Fast JavaScript runtime and package manager
   149→
   150→## Development
   151→
   152→### Run Convex Dev Server
   153→```bash
   154→npx convex dev
   155→```
   156→
   157→### Run Next.js Dev Server
   158→```bash
   159→bun dev
   160→```
   161→
   162→### Build for Production
   163→```bash
   164→bun run build
   165→```
   166→
   167→### Start Production Server
   168→```bash
   169→bun start
   170→```
   171→
   172→## Environment Variables
   173→
   174→### Required (Clerk)
   175→
   176→These must be manually added to `.env.local`:
   177→
   178→- `NEXT_PUBLIC_CLERK_PUBLISHABLE_KEY`: Clerk publishable key (starts with `pk_test_` or `pk_live_`)
   179→- `CLERK_SECRET_KEY`: Clerk secret key (starts with `sk_test_` or `sk_live_`)
   180→- `CLERK_DOMAIN`: Your Clerk domain (e.g., `https://your-app.clerk.accounts.dev`)
   181→- `CLERK_JWT_ISSUER_DOMAIN`: Your Clerk JWT issuer domain (same as `CLERK_DOMAIN`) - **Required for Convex authentication**
   182→
   183→### Auto-Generated (Convex)
   184→
   185→These are automatically created when you run `npx convex dev`:
   186→
   187→- `CONVEX_DEPLOYMENT`: Your Convex deployment identifier
   188→- `NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL`: Public URL for Convex API
   189→
   190→### Recommended (Webhooks)
   191→
   192→- `CLERK_WEBHOOK_SECRET`: For automatic user sync via webhooks (see [Webhook Setup](#webhook-setup-optional-but-recommended) below)
   193→
   194→## Webhook Setup (Optional but Recommended)
   195→
   196→To ensure users are automatically synced to Convex when they sign up, configure Clerk webhooks:
   197→
   198→### Local Development (using ngrok)
   199→
   200→1. **Install ngrok** (if not already installed):
   201→   ```bash
   202→   brew install ngrok
   203→   # or download from https://ngrok.com/download
   204→   ```
   205→
   206→2. **Start your development servers**:
   207→   ```bash
   208→   # Terminal 1: Convex
   209→   npx convex dev
   210→
   211→   # Terminal 2: Next.js
   212→   bun dev
   213→
   214→   # Terminal 3: ngrok tunnel
   215→   ngrok http 3000
   216→   ```
   217→
   218→3. **Configure webhook in Clerk Dashboard**:
   219→   - Copy the HTTPS URL from ngrok (e.g., `https://abc123.ngrok.io`)
   220→   - Go to [Clerk Dashboard](https://dashboard.clerk.com) → Webhooks
   221→   - Click "Add Endpoint"
   222→   - Endpoint URL: `https://abc123.ngrok.io/api/webhook/clerk`
   223→   - Subscribe to events: `user.created`, `user.updated`, `user.deleted`
   224→   - Click "Create"
   225→   - Copy the "Signing Secret" (starts with `whsec_`)
   226→
   227→4. **Add webhook secret to `.env.local`**:
   228→   ```bash
   229→   CLERK_WEBHOOK_SECRET=whsec_your_secret_here
   230→   ```
   231→
   232→5. **Restart your Next.js server** to load the new environment variable
   233→
   234→### Production Deployment
   235→
   236→1. **Configure webhook in Clerk Dashboard**:
   237→   - Go to [Clerk Dashboard](https://dashboard.clerk.com) → Webhooks
   238→   - Click "Add Endpoint"
   239→   - Endpoint URL: `https://your-domain.com/api/webhook/clerk`
   240→   - Subscribe to events: `user.created`, `user.updated`, `user.deleted`
   241→   - Copy the "Signing Secret"
   242→
   243→2. **Add webhook secret to production environment**:
   244→   - Add `CLERK_WEBHOOK_SECRET` to your production environment variables
   245→   - Ensure HTTPS is enabled (required for webhooks)
   246→
   247→### How It Works
   248→
   249→- When a user signs up in Clerk, the webhook immediately creates their profile in Convex
   250→- When a user updates their profile, the changes are synced to Convex
   251→- Client-side sync (`useUserSync` hook) serves as a fallback for reliability
   252→
   253→### Testing the Webhook
   254→
   255→Test that webhooks are working:
   256→
   257→1. Sign up with a new test account
   258→2. Check Convex dashboard → Data → users table
   259→3. User should appear immediately (without visiting dashboard)
   260→4. View ngrok inspector at http://localhost:4040 to see webhook requests
   261→
   262→## Protected Routes
   263→
   264→Routes are automatically protected by the middleware. Configure public routes in `middleware.ts`:
   265→
   266→```typescript
   267→const isPublicRoute = createRouteMatcher([
   268→  "/",               // Home page (public)
   269→  "/sign-in(.*)",   // Clerk sign-in pages
   270→  "/sign-up(.*)",   // Clerk sign-up pages
   271→]);
   272→```
   273→
   274→All other routes require authentication.
   275→
   276→## User Data Access
   277→
   278→### In Client Components
   279→
   280→```typescript
   281→import { useUser } from "@clerk/nextjs";
   282→
   283→const { user, isLoaded, isSignedIn } = useUser();
   284→```
   285→
   286→### In Convex Queries
   287→
   288→```typescript
   289→import { query } from "./_generated/server";
   290→import { getCurrentUser } from "./users";
   291→
   292→export const myQuery = query({
   293→  handler: async (ctx) => {
   294→    const user = await getCurrentUser(ctx);
   295→    // user contains data from Convex users table
   296→  },
   297→});
   298→```
   299→
   300→## Admin Portal
   301→
   302→### Overview
   303→
   304→The admin portal provides role-based access control with a dedicated interface for managing users, configurations, analytics, and system settings. Only users with the `admin` role can access the admin portal.
   305→
   306→### Features
   307→
   308→- **User Management**: View all users, search/filter by name or email, view user roles
   309→- **Configuration Management**: View all widget configurations across all users with search and category filtering
   310→- **Component Library**: Browse and manage UI components (shadcn/ui) and widget components organized by category
   311→- **Complete Widget Previews**: Interactive demos of full widget implementations with live functionality, syntax-highlighted code, and copy-to-clipboard (includes 18-phase onboarding widget)
   312→- **Analytics Dashboard**: Platform usage trends and performance metrics (placeholder - coming soon)
   313→- **System Settings**: Configure system-wide preferences (placeholder - coming soon)
   314→- **Audit Logging**: All admin actions are logged to the `adminLogs` table for security tracking
   315→- **Server-Side Authorization**: All admin queries enforce authorization at the database level
   316→
   317→### Setting Up the First Admin User
   318→
   319→**Important**: By default, all users are created with the `user` role. You must manually set the first admin user via the Convex Dashboard:
   320→
   321→1. **Start your Convex dev server** (if not running):
   322→   ```bash
   323→   npx convex dev
   324→   ```
   325→
   326→2. **Sign in to your app** to create your user record in the database
   327→
   328→3. **Open the Convex Dashboard**:
   329→   - Go to [dashboard.convex.dev](https://dashboard.convex.dev)
   330→   - Navigate to your project
   331→   - Click on "Data" in the sidebar
   332→
   333→4. **Find your user record**:
   334→   - Click on the `users` table
   335→   - Find your user by email or `clerkId`
   336→
   337→5. **Set admin role**:
   338→   - Click the "Edit" button (pencil icon) for your user record
   339→   - Change the `role` field from `"user"` to `"admin"`
   340→   - Click "Save"
   341→
   342→6. **Refresh your app** - you should now see:
   343→   - "Welcome Back Admin!" message on the home page
   344→   - "Admin Portal" button below "Go to Dashboard"
   345→
   346→### Admin Portal Access
   347→
   348→**For Admin Users:**
   349→- Home page shows "Welcome Back Admin!" instead of "Welcome Back!"
   350→- "Admin Portal" button appears on the home page
   351→- Direct access to `/admin` and all admin pages
   352→
   353→**For Regular Users:**
   354→- Home page shows standard "Welcome Back!" message
   355→- No "Admin Portal" button visible
   356→- Attempting to access `/admin` routes results in automatic redirect to `/dashboard`
   357→
   358→### Admin Routes
   359→
   360→- `/admin` - Admin dashboard with user and configuration statistics
   361→- `/admin/users` - User management with search and filtering
   362→- `/admin/configurations` - Configuration management with category filters
   363→- `/admin/components` - Component library overview with statistics
   364→- `/admin/components/ui-components` - Browse shadcn/ui components with search
   365→- `/admin/components/widgets` - Browse widget components organized by category (icons, animations, AI elements, ask-anything, **complete widgets**)
   366→- `/admin/components/widgets/complete/[widget]` - Interactive preview page for complete widget implementations (e.g., onboarding-widget with 18 phases)
   367→- `/admin/analytics` - Analytics dashboard (placeholder)
   368→- `/admin/settings` - System settings (placeholder)
   369→
   370→### Security Considerations
   371→
   372→1. **Server-Side Authorization**: All admin queries use the `requireAdmin()` helper which validates the user's role at the database level before executing any operation
   373→
   374→2. **Client-Side Redirect**: Admin layout includes client-side authorization check with automatic redirect for non-admin users attempting to access admin routes
   375→
   376→3. **Role Immutability**: User roles can only be changed via the Convex Dashboard - there is no UI for users to change their own roles or other users' roles
   377→
   378→4. **Audit Trail**: All admin actions are logged to the `adminLogs` table with admin ID, action type, target user (if applicable), metadata, and timestamp
   379→
   380→5. **Default Permissions**: All new users default to `"user"` role - admin role must be explicitly granted
   381→
   382→### Testing the Admin Portal
   383→
   384→1. Set your user role to `"admin"` in the Convex Dashboard (see setup steps above)
   385→2. Sign in to your app
   386→3. Verify "Welcome Back Admin!" message displays on home page
   387→4. Click "Admin Portal" button
   388→5. Verify admin dashboard loads with statistics
   389→6. Test navigation to Users and Configurations pages
   390→7. Test navigation to Components pages:
   391→   - Click "Components" → "Overview" and verify statistics display (including Complete Widgets count)
   392→   - Click "UI Components" and verify table shows shadcn/ui components
   393→   - Test search functionality on UI Components page
   394→   - Click "Widgets" and verify tabs display for each category (Icons, Animations, AI Elements, Ask Anything, **Widgets**)
   395→   - Click "Widgets" tab and verify onboarding-widget card displays with phase count and component count badges
   396→   - Click "View Preview" on onboarding-widget to open interactive demo
   397→   - Interact with the 18-phase onboarding widget (navigate phases, click suggestions)
   398→   - Toggle dark mode on widget preview
   399→   - Click "Code" tab and verify syntax-highlighted code displays
   400→   - Test copy-to-clipboard functionality on code snippet
   401→   - Navigate back to Widgets tab with "Back to Widgets" button
   402→   - Test search functionality across all widget categories
   403→8. Test search and filter functionality on all pages
   404→9. Sign out and sign in as a regular user
   405→10. Verify no "Admin Portal" button on home page
   406→11. Manually navigate to `/admin` in browser
   407→12. Verify automatic redirect to `/dashboard`
   408→
   409→## Next Steps
   410→
   411→- **Set up Clerk webhooks** (see [Webhook Setup](#webhook-setup-optional-but-recommended) above)
   412→- **Set first admin user** (see [Admin Portal Setup](#setting-up-the-first-admin-user) above)
   413→- Customize the dashboard page with widget configuration UI
   414→- Implement analytics dashboard with real data
   415→- Build the chat widget library
   416→- Implement widget customization settings
   417→
   418→## Documentation
   419→
   420→- **Clerk Migration Guide**: See `ai_docs/clerkmigration.md` for complete Clerk + Convex integration details
   421→- **Next.js 16 Docs**: See `ai_docs/next_js_docs/next_js_update.md`
   422→- **React 19.2 Docs**: See `ai_docs/react_docs/react_update.md`
   423→

# Gist Widget Builder

A Next.js 16 application with Clerk authentication and Convex backend.

## Setup Instructions

### 1. Install Dependencies

```bash
bun install
```

### 2. Set Up Clerk Authentication

1. Create a Clerk account at https://clerk.com
2. Create a new application in the Clerk Dashboard
3. Copy your API keys from the **API Keys** page

### 3. Configure Environment Variables

Create or update `.env.local` with your Clerk keys:

```bash
# Clerk Authentication
NEXT_PUBLIC_CLERK_PUBLISHABLE_KEY=pk_test_...
CLERK_SECRET_KEY=sk_test_...
CLERK_DOMAIN=https://your-app.clerk.accounts.dev
CLERK_JWT_ISSUER_DOMAIN=https://your-app.clerk.accounts.dev

# Clerk Webhook (for automatic user sync)
CLERK_WEBHOOK_SECRET=whsec_...

# Convex (auto-generated by npx convex dev)
CONVEX_DEPLOYMENT=dev:...
NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL=https://....convex.cloud
```

**Note**: The `CLERK_JWT_ISSUER_DOMAIN` is required for Convex to validate Clerk JWT tokens. It should match your Clerk Frontend API URL (same as `CLERK_DOMAIN`). The `CLERK_WEBHOOK_SECRET` is required for automatic user synchronization. See the [Webhook Setup](#webhook-setup-optional-but-recommended) section below for configuration instructions.

### 4. Set Convex Environment Variable

**Important**: The `CLERK_JWT_ISSUER_DOMAIN` must also be configured in the Convex Dashboard:

1. Go to [Convex Dashboard → Environment Variables](https://dashboard.convex.dev)
2. Navigate to your project settings → Environment Variables
3. Click "Add Environment Variable"
4. Add:
   - **Name**: `CLERK_JWT_ISSUER_DOMAIN`
   - **Value**: `https://your-app.clerk.accounts.dev` (same as your `CLERK_DOMAIN`)
5. Click "Save"

This step is **required** for Clerk-Convex authentication to work properly.

### 5. Initialize Convex Project

Run the following command to create/link a Convex project:

```bash
npx convex dev
```

This will:
- Create a Convex project (or link to existing one)
- Generate Convex environment variables in `.env.local`
- Deploy the database schema (users table)
- Start the Convex development server
- Watch for changes in the `convex/` directory

### 6. Start the Next.js Development Server

In a **separate terminal**, run:

```bash
bun dev
```

Your app will be available at [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000)

## Project Structure

```
/app
  /layout.tsx              # Root layout with ClerkProvider
  /ConvexClientProvider.tsx # Client-side Convex provider with Clerk integration
  /page.tsx                # Home page with sign in/up buttons
  /dashboard
    /page.tsx              # Protected dashboard page
  /globals.css             # Tailwind + shadcn CSS variables

/components
  /ui                      # shadcn components (button, card, input, label, form)
  /Header.tsx              # Header with Clerk authentication UI

/convex
  /schema.ts               # Database schema (users table)
  /auth.config.ts          # Clerk authentication configuration
  /users.ts                # User queries and helpers
  /_generated              # Auto-generated types (created by Convex)

/lib
  /utils.ts                # Utility functions (cn helper)

/middleware.ts             # Clerk authentication middleware (route protection)
```

## Features

- **Authentication**: Clerk authentication with pre-built UI components
- **Protected Routes**: Middleware-based route protection (automatic)
- **Real-time Database**: Convex backend with type-safe queries
- **User Management**: Automatic user sync from Clerk to Convex
- **Admin Portal**: Role-based access control with dedicated admin interface
- **shadcn/ui**: Beautiful, accessible UI components
- **TypeScript**: Full type safety throughout the application
- **Next.js 16 Compatible**: Works with latest Next.js async APIs

## Authentication Flow

1. **Sign Up**: Users click "Sign Up" button → Clerk modal opens → Create account
2. **Sign In**: Users click "Sign In" button → Clerk modal opens → Authenticate
3. **User Sync**: User data automatically synced to Convex database
4. **Dashboard**: Protected route accessible only when authenticated
5. **Sign Out**: Click UserButton (top right) → Sign out

## Architecture

```
User → Clerk (Auth UI) → JWT Token → Next.js App → Convex Database
              ↓                                         ↓
    ClerkProvider → ConvexProviderWithClerk → Authenticated Queries
```

**Key Components:**
- **Clerk**: Authentication provider (UI, sessions, JWTs)
- **Convex**: Database backend (users table, queries)
- **Middleware**: Automatic route protection (public vs protected)
- **ConvexProviderWithClerk**: Connects Clerk auth with Convex queries

## Tech Stack

- **Next.js 16**: React framework with App Router and Turbopack
- **React 19.2**: Latest React with modern hooks and patterns
- **Clerk**: Authentication and user management platform
- **Convex**: Backend-as-a-service with real-time database
- **shadcn/ui**: Component library built on Radix UI
- **Tailwind CSS**: Utility-first CSS framework
- **TypeScript 5.9.3**: Type-safe development
- **Bun 1.3.1**: Fast JavaScript runtime and package manager

## Development

### Run Convex Dev Server
```bash
npx convex dev
```

### Run Next.js Dev Server
```bash
bun dev
```

### Build for Production
```bash
bun run build
```

### Start Production Server
```bash
bun start
```

## Environment Variables

### Required (Clerk)

These must be manually added to `.env.local`:

- `NEXT_PUBLIC_CLERK_PUBLISHABLE_KEY`: Clerk publishable key (starts with `pk_test_` or `pk_live_`)
- `CLERK_SECRET_KEY`: Clerk secret key (starts with `sk_test_` or `sk_live_`)
- `CLERK_DOMAIN`: Your Clerk domain (e.g., `https://your-app.clerk.accounts.dev`)
- `CLERK_JWT_ISSUER_DOMAIN`: Your Clerk JWT issuer domain (same as `CLERK_DOMAIN`) - **Required for Convex authentication**

### Auto-Generated (Convex)

These are automatically created when you run `npx convex dev`:

- `CONVEX_DEPLOYMENT`: Your Convex deployment identifier
- `NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL`: Public URL for Convex API

### Recommended (Webhooks)

- `CLERK_WEBHOOK_SECRET`: For automatic user sync via webhooks (see [Webhook Setup](#webhook-setup-optional-but-recommended) below)

## Webhook Setup (Optional but Recommended)

To ensure users are automatically synced to Convex when they sign up, configure Clerk webhooks:

### Local Development (using ngrok)

1. **Install ngrok** (if not already installed):
   ```bash
   brew install ngrok
   # or download from https://ngrok.com/download
   ```

2. **Start your development servers**:
   ```bash
   # Terminal 1: Convex
   npx convex dev

   # Terminal 2: Next.js
   bun dev

   # Terminal 3: ngrok tunnel
   ngrok http 3000
   ```

3. **Configure webhook in Clerk Dashboard**:
   - Copy the HTTPS URL from ngrok (e.g., `https://abc123.ngrok.io`)
   - Go to [Clerk Dashboard](https://dashboard.clerk.com) → Webhooks
   - Click "Add Endpoint"
   - Endpoint URL: `https://abc123.ngrok.io/api/webhook/clerk`
   - Subscribe to events: `user.created`, `user.updated`, `user.deleted`
   - Click "Create"
   - Copy the "Signing Secret" (starts with `whsec_`)

4. **Add webhook secret to `.env.local`**:
   ```bash
   CLERK_WEBHOOK_SECRET=whsec_your_secret_here
   ```

5. **Restart your Next.js server** to load the new environment variable

### Production Deployment

1. **Configure webhook in Clerk Dashboard**:
   - Go to [Clerk Dashboard](https://dashboard.clerk.com) → Webhooks
   - Click "Add Endpoint"
   - Endpoint URL: `https://your-domain.com/api/webhook/clerk`
   - Subscribe to events: `user.created`, `user.updated`, `user.deleted`
   - Copy the "Signing Secret"

2. **Add webhook secret to production environment**:
   - Add `CLERK_WEBHOOK_SECRET` to your production environment variables
   - Ensure HTTPS is enabled (required for webhooks)

### How It Works

- When a user signs up in Clerk, the webhook immediately creates their profile in Convex
- When a user updates their profile, the changes are synced to Convex
- Client-side sync (`useUserSync` hook) serves as a fallback for reliability

### Testing the Webhook

Test that webhooks are working:

1. Sign up with a new test account
2. Check Convex dashboard → Data → users table
3. User should appear immediately (without visiting dashboard)
4. View ngrok inspector at http://localhost:4040 to see webhook requests

## Protected Routes

Routes are automatically protected by the middleware. Configure public routes in `middleware.ts`:

```typescript
const isPublicRoute = createRouteMatcher([
  "/",               // Home page (public)
  "/sign-in(.*)",   // Clerk sign-in pages
  "/sign-up(.*)",   // Clerk sign-up pages
]);
```

All other routes require authentication.

## User Data Access

### In Client Components

```typescript
import { useUser } from "@clerk/nextjs";

const { user, isLoaded, isSignedIn } = useUser();
```

### In Convex Queries

```typescript
import { query } from "./_generated/server";
import { getCurrentUser } from "./users";

export const myQuery = query({
  handler: async (ctx) => {
    const user = await getCurrentUser(ctx);
    // user contains data from Convex users table
  },
});
```

## Admin Portal

### Overview

The admin portal provides role-based access control with a dedicated interface for managing users, configurations, analytics, and system settings. Only users with the `admin` role can access the admin portal.

### Features

- **User Management**: View all users, search/filter by name or email, view user roles
- **Configuration Management**: View all widget configurations across all users with search and category filtering
- **Component Library**: Browse and manage UI components (shadcn/ui) and widget components organized by category
- **Complete Widget Previews**: Interactive demos of full widget implementations with live functionality, syntax-highlighted code, and copy-to-clipboard (includes 18-phase onboarding widget)
- **Analytics Dashboard**: Platform usage trends and performance metrics (placeholder - coming soon)
- **System Settings**: Configure system-wide preferences (placeholder - coming soon)
- **Audit Logging**: All admin actions are logged to the `adminLogs` table for security tracking
- **Server-Side Authorization**: All admin queries enforce authorization at the database level

### Setting Up the First Admin User

**Important**: By default, all users are created with the `user` role. You must manually set the first admin user via the Convex Dashboard:

1. **Start your Convex dev server** (if not running):
   ```bash
   npx convex dev
   ```

2. **Sign in to your app** to create your user record in the database

3. **Open the Convex Dashboard**:
   - Go to [dashboard.convex.dev](https://dashboard.convex.dev)
   - Navigate to your project
   - Click on "Data" in the sidebar

4. **Find your user record**:
   - Click on the `users` table
   - Find your user by email or `clerkId`

5. **Set admin role**:
   - Click the "Edit" button (pencil icon) for your user record
   - Change the `role` field from `"user"` to `"admin"`
   - Click "Save"

6. **Refresh your app** - you should now see:
   - "Welcome Back Admin!" message on the home page
   - "Admin Portal" button below "Go to Dashboard"

### Admin Portal Access

**For Admin Users:**
- Home page shows "Welcome Back Admin!" instead of "Welcome Back!"
- "Admin Portal" button appears on the home page
- Direct access to `/admin` and all admin pages

**For Regular Users:**
- Home page shows standard "Welcome Back!" message
- No "Admin Portal" button visible
- Attempting to access `/admin` routes results in automatic redirect to `/dashboard`

### Admin Routes

- `/admin` - Admin dashboard with user and configuration statistics
- `/admin/users` - User management with search and filtering
- `/admin/configurations` - Configuration management with category filters
- `/admin/components` - Component library overview with statistics
- `/admin/components/ui-components` - Browse shadcn/ui components with search
- `/admin/components/widgets` - Browse widget components organized by category (icons, animations, AI elements, ask-anything, **complete widgets**)
- `/admin/components/widgets/complete/[widget]` - Interactive preview page for complete widget implementations (e.g., onboarding-widget with 18 phases)
- `/admin/analytics` - Analytics dashboard (placeholder)
- `/admin/settings` - System settings (placeholder)

### Security Considerations

1. **Server-Side Authorization**: All admin queries use the `requireAdmin()` helper which validates the user's role at the database level before executing any operation

2. **Client-Side Redirect**: Admin layout includes client-side authorization check with automatic redirect for non-admin users attempting to access admin routes

3. **Role Immutability**: User roles can only be changed via the Convex Dashboard - there is no UI for users to change their own roles or other users' roles

4. **Audit Trail**: All admin actions are logged to the `adminLogs` table with admin ID, action type, target user (if applicable), metadata, and timestamp

5. **Default Permissions**: All new users default to `"user"` role - admin role must be explicitly granted

### Testing the Admin Portal

1. Set your user role to `"admin"` in the Convex Dashboard (see setup steps above)
2. Sign in to your app
3. Verify "Welcome Back Admin!" message displays on home page
4. Click "Admin Portal" button
5. Verify admin dashboard loads with statistics
6. Test navigation to Users and Configurations pages
7. Test navigation to Components pages:
   - Click "Components" → "Overview" and verify statistics display (including Complete Widgets count)
   - Click "UI Components" and verify table shows shadcn/ui components
   - Test search functionality on UI Components page
   - Click "Widgets" and verify tabs display for each category (Icons, Animations, AI Elements, Ask Anything, **Widgets**)
   - Click "Widgets" tab and verify onboarding-widget card displays with phase count and component count badges
   - Click "View Preview" on onboarding-widget to open interactive demo
   - Interact with the 18-phase onboarding widget (navigate phases, click suggestions)
   - Toggle dark mode on widget preview
   - Click "Code" tab and verify syntax-highlighted code displays
   - Test copy-to-clipboard functionality on code snippet
   - Navigate back to Widgets tab with "Back to Widgets" button
   - Test search functionality across all widget categories
8. Test search and filter functionality on all pages
9. Sign out and sign in as a regular user
10. Verify no "Admin Portal" button on home page
11. Manually navigate to `/admin` in browser
12. Verify automatic redirect to `/dashboard`

## Next Steps

- **Set up Clerk webhooks** (see [Webhook Setup](#webhook-setup-optional-but-recommended) above)
- **Set first admin user** (see [Admin Portal Setup](#setting-up-the-first-admin-user) above)
- Customize the dashboard page with widget configuration UI
- Implement analytics dashboard with real data
- Build the chat widget library
- Implement widget customization settings

## Documentation

- **Clerk Migration Guide**: See `ai_docs/clerkmigration.md` for complete Clerk + Convex integration details
- **Next.js 16 Docs**: See `ai_docs/next_js_docs/next_js_update.md`
- **React 19.2 Docs**: See `ai_docs/react_docs/react_update.md`

content.text:
# Codebase Summary

## 🎯 **Project**: Gist Widget Builder

**Purpose**: Two-phase chat widget management system
- **Phase 1** (✅ Complete): Admin console with component library
- **Phase 2** (🔄 Pending): Embeddable, customizable chat widget library

---

## 🛠️ **Tech Stack**

**Runtime**: Bun 1.3.1 | **Framework**: Next.js 16 (Turbopack) + React 19.2 | **Language**: TypeScript 5.9.3
**Auth**: Clerk (webhook + client fallback) | **Database**: Convex | **UI**: shadcn/ui + Tailwind CSS v4

---

## 🏗️ **Architecture**

```
User → Clerk (JWT) → Next.js → Convex
         ↓ webhook
      User Sync
```

**Auth Flow**: Dual-layer (webhook primary, client fallback)
**Routes**: Public: `/`, `/sign-in`, `/sign-up`, `/api/webhook` | Protected: all others
**Providers**: ClerkProvider → ConvexProviderWithClerk → App

---

## ✅ **Phase 1 Complete Features**

**Auth & User Management**:
- Clerk auth + protected routes
- Webhook user sync to Convex (with client fallback)
- Role-based access control (admin/user)

**Admin Portal** (`/admin`):
- Users management (search, filter, view roles)
- Configuration management (widget configs across users)
- **Component Library**:
  - UI Components (shadcn/ui browse)
  - Widget Components (organized by category: icons, animations, AI elements, ask-anything, **complete widgets**)
  - **Complete Widget Previews** (`/admin/components/widgets/complete/[widget]`):
    - Interactive demos (e.g., 18-phase onboarding widget)
    - Syntax-highlighted code display
    - Copy-to-clipboard functionality
- Analytics (placeholder), Settings (placeholder)
- Audit logging (all admin actions tracked)
- Server-side authorization (`requireAdmin()`)

**Dashboard** (`/dashboard`):
- Gist Answers config form (RSS feeds, terms, widget settings)
- Install widget page

**Database** (Convex):
- `users`, `gistConfigurations`, `adminLogs`, `componentPreviews`, `components` tables

---

## 📁 **Key Files**

**Auth & Routes**:
- `proxy.ts` - Route protection (Next.js 16 proxy system)
- `app/api/webhook/clerk/route.ts` - Webhook user sync
- `lib/hooks/useUserSync.ts` - Client-side sync fallback

**Database**:
- `convex/schema.ts` - DB schema
- `convex/users.ts`, `convex/admin.ts`, `convex/components.ts` - Queries/mutations

**UI**:
- `components/AdminSidebar.tsx` - Admin navigation
- `components/DashboardSidebar.tsx` - User navigation
- `components/ComponentPreview.tsx` - Widget preview system
- `components/widget_components/complete/onboarding-widget.tsx` - 18-phase onboarding demo

**Config**:
- `next.config.ts` - Next.js 16 config (Turbopack, images, async APIs)
- `components.json` - shadcn/ui config
- `tailwind.config.ts` - Tailwind v4 + shadcn

---

## 🔐 **Admin Setup**

**First Admin User**:
1. Sign in to app → creates user in Convex
2. Open Convex Dashboard → Data → `users` table
3. Edit your user → change `role` from `"user"` to `"admin"`
4. Refresh app → "Admin Portal" button appears

**Admin Features**:
- "Welcome Back Admin!" message
- Access to `/admin/*` routes
- User/config management, component library, audit logs
- Non-admin users → auto-redirect to `/dashboard`

---

## 🔄 **Phase 2 (Pending)**

- Embeddable chat widget library
- Real-time chat functionality
- Widget customization API
- Analytics dashboard (real data)
- Advanced component usage tracking

---

## 🚀 **Dev Workflow**

```bash
# Terminal 1: Convex
npx convex dev

# Terminal 2: Next.js
bun dev

# Terminal 3: ngrok (for webhook testing)
ngrok http 3000
```

**Env Vars**: `NEXT_PUBLIC_CLERK_PUBLISHABLE_KEY`, `CLERK_SECRET_KEY`, `CLERK_WEBHOOK_SECRET`, `NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL`, `CLERK_JWT_ISSUER_DOMAIN` (required in Convex Dashboard)

---

**Context Loaded**: 166 tracked files, complete component library with interactive previews, dual-layer auth system, role-based admin portal, Convex schema with 8 tables.

# Implement the following plan
Follow the `Instructions` to implement the `Plan` then `Report` the completed work.

## Instructions
- Read the plan, think hard about the plan and implement the plan.

## Plan
specs/widget-preview-flow.md

## Report
- Summarize the work you've just done in a concise bullet point list.
- Report the files and total lines changed with `git diff --stat`
I'll read the plan, implement it, and report the completed work.

1→# Feature: Widget Preview Flow for Landing Page
     2→
     3→## Feature Description
     4→Implement a comprehensive widget preview flow that allows unauthenticated users to experience the platform before signing up. Users can enter a Gist API key, choose from 3 widget types (floating, rufus, womensWorld), configure widget appearance (colors, gradients, icons), preview the widget in a demo HTML site, and seamlessly convert their preview configuration into a saved configuration upon sign-up. The system will use ephemeral preview configurations stored in Convex that are automatically cleaned up if the user exits the flow, but persist to the user's account if they complete sign-up/sign-in.
     5→
     6→## User Story
     7→As a prospective user visiting the landing page
     8→I want to preview and configure a widget before creating an account
     9→So that I can understand the platform's capabilities and see my customizations before committing to sign-up
    10→
    11→## Problem Statement
    12→Currently, users must sign up before experiencing the widget configuration capabilities. This creates friction in the user journey and reduces conversion rates. Users cannot evaluate whether the platform meets their needs without creating an account first. There is no way for users to trial the widget customization experience or see how their branding would look in the widgets.
    13→
    14→## Solution Statement
    15→Create a multi-step preview flow starting from the landing page that guides users through:
    16→1. API key entry (validation is permissive - any input accepted for preview purposes)
    17→2. Widget type selection (floating, rufus, or womensWorld)
    18→3. Configuration customization (colors/gradients, icons, dimensions, behavior)
    19→4. Live preview in a demo HTML site
    20→5. Seamless conversion to authenticated user with configuration preservation
    21→
    22→The solution uses a `previewConfigurations` table in Convex to store ephemeral preview data, automatically cleaning up abandoned previews while preserving completed ones through the sign-up process.

   489→## Notes

# Feature: Widget Preview Flow for Landing Page

## Feature Description
Implement a comprehensive widget preview flow that allows unauthenticated users to experience the platform before signing up. Users can enter a Gist API key, choose from 3 widget types (floating, rufus, womensWorld), configure widget appearance (colors, gradients, icons), preview the widget in a demo HTML site, and seamlessly convert their preview configuration into a saved configuration upon sign-up. The system will use ephemeral preview configurations stored in Convex that are automatically cleaned up if the user exits the flow, but persist to the user's account if they complete sign-up/sign-in.

## User Story
As a prospective user visiting the landing page
I want to preview and configure a widget before creating an account
So that I can understand the platform's capabilities and see my customizations before committing to sign-up

## Problem Statement
Currently, users must sign up before experiencing the widget configuration capabilities. This creates friction in the user journey and reduces conversion rates. Users cannot evaluate whether the platform meets their needs without creating an account first. There is no way for users to trial the widget customization experience or see how their branding would look in the widgets.

## Solution Statement
Create a multi-step preview flow starting from the landing page that guides users through:
1. API key entry (validation is permissive - any input accepted for preview purposes)
2. Widget type selection (floating, rufus, or womensWorld)
3. Configuration customization (colors/gradients, icons, dimensions, behavior)
4. Live preview in a demo HTML site
5. Seamless conversion to authenticated user with configuration preservation

The solution uses a `previewConfigurations` table in Convex to store ephemeral preview data, automatically cleaning up abandoned previews while preserving completed ones through the sign-up process.

## Relevant Files
Use these files to implement the feature:

### Existing Files
- **`app/page.tsx`** - Landing page where "Preview Widget" button will be added
  - Add new button to trigger preview flow
  - Maintain existing authenticated/unauthenticated state handling

- **`convex/schema.ts`** - Database schema definitions
  - Add new `previewConfigurations` table schema
  - Reference existing widget configuration schema patterns

- **`app/dashboard/configure-widget/page.tsx`** - Existing widget configuration page
  - Reference form structure and validation patterns
  - Reuse widget type selection patterns
  - Adapt configuration form logic

- **`convex/gistConfigurations.ts`** - Widget configuration mutations/queries
  - Reference save configuration patterns
  - Create preview-specific mutations

- **`components/ui/**`** - shadcn/ui components for forms and UI elements
  - Button, Card, Input, Select, RadioGroup, Slider, Badge, Dialog, Tabs

- **`lib/utils.ts`** - Utility functions including `cn()` helper

- **`proxy.ts`** - Route protection middleware (Clerk)

## Testing Strategy

### Unit Tests

### Integration Tests
- **Preview Flow Navigation**

  - Test back navigation and state preservation

- **Configuration Persistence**
  - Test saving configuration to previewConfigurations
  - Test retrieving configuration across stages
  - Test real-time preview updates

- **Sign-Up Conversion**
  - Test preview configuration retrieval after sign-up
  - Test conversion to user configuration
  - Test cleanup of preview configuration

### Edge Cases
- **Session Expiration**
  - Test behavior when preview session expires during flow
  - Verify automatic cleanup of expired sessions

- **Multiple Previews**
  - Test creating multiple preview sessions from same browser
  - Verify each session is isolated

- **Abandoned Previews**
  - Test automatic cleanup of abandoned previews after 24 hours
  - Verify no data leaks

- **Browser Refresh**
  - Test state restoration after browser refresh
  - Verify session ID persists in localStorage

- **Authentication Edge Cases**
  - Test preview flow when user is already authenticated
  - Test sign-in vs sign-up conversion paths
  - Test configuration merge if user already has configurations

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Unauthenticated users can access the preview flow from the landing page
- [ ] API key entry accepts any non-empty input and creates a preview session
- [ ] Users can select from 3 widget types (floating, rufus, womensWorld)
- [ ] Configuration page allows customization of colors/gradients, dimensions, and behavior
- [ ] Live preview updates in real-time as configuration changes
- [ ] Demo page displays configured widget in full-page HTML site
- [ ] "Like this? Create an account" CTA triggers sign-up flow
- [ ] Preview configuration is converted to user configuration after successful sign-up
- [ ] Abandoned previews are automatically cleaned up after 24 hours
- [ ] Exit from preview flow shows confirmation dialog
- [ ] Preview configuration is deleted on explicit exit
- [ ] All preview routes are public (not protected by authentication)
- [ ] Session ID persists across page refreshes via localStorage
- [ ] Multiple preview sessions from same browser are isolated
- [ ] No TypeScript or build errors
- [ ] Zero regressions in existing functionality

## Validation Commands
Execute every command to validate the feature works correctly with zero regressions.

- `bun run build` - Build the Next.js app to validate no TypeScript or build errors
- `npx convex dev` - Deploy Convex schema and functions (run in background)
- `bun dev` - Start the Next.js dev server and manually test the feature end-to-end
- `bun test` - Run tests to validate the feature works with zero regressions (if tests exist)

### Manual Testing Checklist
1. **Landing Page**
   - [ ] "Preview Widget" button visible for unauthenticated users
   - [ ] Button links to `/preview` route

2. **API Key Entry**
   - [ ] Form accepts any non-empty input
   - [ ] Loading state displays during session creation
   - [ ] Navigation to widget type selection on success

3. **Widget Type Selection**
   - [ ] All 3 widget types displayed with visual cards
   - [ ] Widget type selection persists in preview configuration
   - [ ] Navigation to configuration page on selection

4. **Configuration Page**
   - [ ] Tabs switch between Basics, Appearance, and Behavior sections
   - [ ] Color picker updates preview in real-time
   - [ ] Gradient picker creates proper gradients
   - [ ] Dimension sliders update widget size
   - [ ] Placement options change widget position in preview
   - [ ] Configuration saves to Convex (debounced)
   - [ ] "Preview in Demo" button navigates to demo page

5. **Demo Preview**
   - [ ] Widget renders with user configuration
   - [ ] All widget interactions work (open, close, etc.)
   - [ ] CTA button displays prominently
   - [ ] CTA links to sign-up flow

6. **Sign-Up Conversion**
   - [ ] Sign-up flow preserves preview session ID
   - [ ] Preview configuration converts to user configuration
   - [ ] User redirected to dashboard after sign-up
   - [ ] Configuration visible in dashboard
   - [ ] Preview configuration deleted from previewConfigurations table

7. **Exit Handling**
   - [ ] Dialog appears when navigating away from preview
   - [ ] Dialog allows continue or cancel
   - [ ] Preview configuration deleted on explicit exit

8. **Cleanup Automation**
   - [ ] Expired previews (>24 hours) are deleted by scheduled job
   - [ ] No orphaned preview configurations remain

## Notes

### Technology Stack Integration
- **Bun 1.3.1**: Use `bun dev`, `bun run build`, and `bun add` for all package management
- **Next.js 16**: Use App Router with async components and React Server Components where appropriate
- **React 19.2**: Use latest hooks and patterns (no forwardRef needed for ref props in function components)
- **Convex**: Real-time database with automatic schema migrations
- **Clerk**: Authentication with webhook-based user sync

### Design Considerations
- **Color/Gradient Picker**: Consider using a library like `react-colorful` (add via `bun add react-colorful`) or building a custom picker following shadcn/ui patterns
- **Icon Upload**: Reference favicon upload implementation in `app/dashboard/page.tsx` for file handling patterns
- **Session TTL**: 24 hours is a reasonable default, but can be adjusted based on user feedback
- **Preview Limit**: Consider adding rate limiting to prevent abuse (e.g., max 10 previews per IP per hour)

### Future Enhancements
- **Preview Sharing**: Allow users to share preview link with team members
- **Preview Templates**: Pre-configured templates for common use cases
- **Advanced Customization**: Custom CSS injection, font selection, animation preferences
- **A/B Testing**: Track conversion rates from preview to sign-up
- **Preview Analytics**: Track which configurations lead to sign-ups

### Security Considerations
- **Session Validation**: Always validate preview session ID before allowing configuration updates
- **Rate Limiting**: Implement rate limiting on preview creation to prevent abuse
- **XSS Protection**: Sanitize all user inputs, especially in demo preview rendering
- **CSRF Protection**: Use Convex's built-in authentication for all mutations

### Performance Optimizations
- **Debounced Saves**: Configuration changes should be debounced (500ms) before saving to Convex
- **Optimistic Updates**: Use optimistic updates for smooth UI during configuration changes
- **Lazy Loading**: Lazy load widget preview renderer for faster initial page load
- **Code Splitting**: Split preview flow routes to reduce initial bundle size

### Accessibility Considerations
- **Keyboard Navigation**: Ensure all preview stages can be navigated via keyboard
- **Screen Reader Support**: Add proper ARIA labels and descriptions
- **Focus Management**: Manage focus when navigating between preview stages
- **Color Contrast**: Ensure color picker shows contrast ratio warnings for accessibility

1→import { defineSchema, defineTable } from "convex/server";
     2→import { v } from "convex/values";
     3→
     4→/**
     5→ * Convex Database Schema
     6→ *
     7→ * Type Safety Enhancements (Breaking Changes):
     8→ * - Strong enum validation for category and ingestionMethod
     9→ * - Proper record type for customHeaders
    10→ * - Primary RSS URL merged into rssFeeds[0]
    11→ *
    12→ * Security Warning:
    13→ * - RSS feed passwords stored in plain text (see userProfiles table notes)
    14→ */
    15→
    16→export default defineSchema(
    17→  {
    18→  // Users table (synced from Clerk)
    19→  // Purpose: Authentication data only (Clerk webhook sync)
    20→  // Related: userProfiles table for extended business data
    21→  users: defineTable({
    22→    clerkId: v.string(),
    23→    email: v.string(),
    24→    name: v.optional(v.string()),
    25→    imageUrl: v.optional(v.string()),
    26→    role: v.union(v.literal("user"), v.literal("admin")),
    27→    createdAt: v.number(),
    28→  })
    29→    .index("by_clerk_id", ["clerkId"])
    30→    .index("by_email", ["email"])
    31→    .index("by_role", ["role"]),
    32→
    33→  // User Profiles table
    34→  // Purpose: Extended user information beyond authentication
    35→  // Separation: Authentication (users) vs. Business Logic (userProfiles)
    36→  userProfiles: defineTable({
    37→    userId: v.string(), // Reference to users.clerkId
    38→
    39→    // Company Information
    40→    companyName: v.optional(v.string()),
    41→    jobTitle: v.optional(v.string()),
    42→    industry: v.optional(v.string()),
    43→    companySize: v.optional(
    44→      v.union(
    45→        v.literal("1-10"),
    46→        v.literal("11-50"),
    47→        v.literal("51-200"),
    48→        v.literal("201-1000"),
    49→        v.literal("1000+")
    50→      )
    51→    ),
    52→
    53→    // Subscription & Trial
    54→    subscriptionTier: v.union(
    55→      v.literal("free"),
    56→      v.literal("pro"),
    57→      v.literal("enterprise")
    58→    ),
    59→    isTrialActive: v.boolean(),
    60→    trialEndsAt: v.optional(v.number()),
    61→
    62→    // User Preferences
    63→    preferences: v.optional(
    64→      v.object({
    65→        theme: v.optional(v.union(v.literal("light"), v.literal("dark"), v.literal("system"))),
    66→        emailNotifications: v.optional(v.boolean()),
    67→        language: v.optional(v.string()), // ISO 639-1 code (en, es, fr, etc.)
    68→      })
    69→    ),
    70→
    71→    // Onboarding
    72→    onboardingCompleted: v.boolean(),
    73→    onboardingStep: v.optional(v.number()),
    74→
    75→    // Timestamps
    76→    createdAt: v.number(),
    77→    updatedAt: v.number(),
    78→  })
    79→    .index("by_user_id", ["userId"])
    80→    .index("by_subscription", ["subscriptionTier"]),
    81→
    82→  // Admin Action Logs
    83→  // Purpose: Audit trail for administrative actions
    84→  adminLogs: defineTable({
    85→    adminId: v.id("users"), // Admin who performed action
    86→    action: v.string(), // Description of action
    87→    targetUserId: v.optional(v.id("users")), // User affected by action
    88→    metadata: v.optional(v.any()), // Additional context
    89→    timestamp: v.number(), // When action occurred
    90→  })
    91→    .index("by_admin_id", ["adminId"])
    92→    .index("by_timestamp", ["timestamp"])
    93→    .index("by_target_user", ["targetUserId"]),
    94→
    95→  // Gist Answers configurations
    96→  // Purpose: Content ingestion settings per user
    97→  gistConfigurations: defineTable({
    98→    userId: v.string(), // Reference to user's Clerk ID
    99→
   100→    // Publication Details
   101→    publicationName: v.string(),
   102→
   103→    // Category (Strong enum validation - 12 valid categories)
   104→    category: v.union(
   105→      v.literal("Academic"),
   106→      v.literal("Books"),
   107→      v.literal("Business"),
   108→      v.literal("gpa_publisher"),
   109→      v.literal("Health"),
   110→      v.literal("Lifestyle"),
   111→      v.literal("News"),
   112→      v.literal("Other"),
   113→      v.literal("ProRata Internal"),
   114→      v.literal("Reference"),
   115→      v.literal("Sports"),
   116→      v.literal("Uncategorized")
   117→    ),
   118→
   119→    // Ingestion Method (Strong enum validation)
   120→    ingestionMethod: v.union(
   121→      v.literal("wordpress"),
   122→      v.literal("rss")
   123→    ),
   124→
   125→    // WordPress Configuration
   126→    wordpressUrl: v.optional(v.string()),
   127→
   128→    // RSS Feeds Configuration
   129→    // Note: Primary RSS URL is stored in rssFeeds[0]
   130→    // Security Warning: Passwords stored in plain text
   131→    // TODO: Implement encryption for sensitive fields
   132→    rssFeeds: v.optional(
   133→      v.array(
   134→        v.object({
   135→          url: v.string(),
   136→          username: v.optional(v.string()),
   137→          password: v.optional(v.string()), // ⚠️ Plain text - security concern
   138→          countStart: v.optional(v.number()),
   139→          countIncrement: v.optional(v.number()),
   140→          // Custom HTTP headers (key-value pairs)
   141→          customHeaders: v.optional(v.record(v.string(), v.string())),
   142→        })
   143→      )
   144→    ),
   145→
   146→    // Favicon
   147→    faviconStorageId: v.optional(v.id("_storage")),
   148→    faviconUrl: v.optional(v.string()),
   149→
   150→    // Terms & Conditions
   151→    termsAccepted: v.boolean(),
   152→    termsAcceptedAt: v.optional(v.number()),
   153→
   154→    // Timestamps
   155→    createdAt: v.number(),
   156→    updatedAt: v.number(),
   157→  }).index("by_user_id", ["userId"]),
   158→},
   159→  { strictTableNameTypes: true }
   160→);
   161→

1→import { mutation, query } from "./_generated/server";
     2→import { v } from "convex/values";
     3→
     4→// Get user's configuration
     5→export const getUserConfiguration = query({
     6→  handler: async (ctx) => {
     7→    const identity = await ctx.auth.getUserIdentity();
     8→    if (!identity) {
     9→      return null;
    10→    }
    11→
    12→    const config = await ctx.db
    13→      .query("gistConfigurations")
    14→      .withIndex("by_user_id", (q) => q.eq("userId", identity.subject))
    15→      .first();
    16→
    17→    return config;
    18→  },
    19→});
    20→
    21→// Save or update configuration
    22→export const saveConfiguration = mutation({
    23→  args: {
    24→    publicationName: v.string(),
    25→    // Strong enum validation for category (12 valid categories)
    26→    category: v.union(
    27→      v.literal("Academic"),
    28→      v.literal("Books"),
    29→      v.literal("Business"),
    30→      v.literal("gpa_publisher"),
    31→      v.literal("Health"),
    32→      v.literal("Lifestyle"),
    33→      v.literal("News"),
    34→      v.literal("Other"),
    35→      v.literal("ProRata Internal"),
    36→      v.literal("Reference"),
    37→      v.literal("Sports"),
    38→      v.literal("Uncategorized")
    39→    ),
    40→    // Strong enum validation for ingestion method
    41→    ingestionMethod: v.union(
    42→      v.literal("wordpress"),
    43→      v.literal("rss")
    44→    ),
    45→    wordpressUrl: v.optional(v.string()),
    46→    // RSS feeds array (includes primary RSS URL as first element)
    47→    rssFeeds: v.optional(
    48→      v.array(
    49→        v.object({
    50→          url: v.string(),
    51→          username: v.optional(v.string()),
    52→          password: v.optional(v.string()),
    53→          countStart: v.optional(v.number()),
    54→          countIncrement: v.optional(v.number()),
    55→          // Fixed: Proper record type for custom headers
    56→          customHeaders: v.optional(v.record(v.string(), v.string())),
    57→        })
    58→      )
    59→    ),
    60→    faviconStorageId: v.optional(v.id("_storage")),
    61→    termsAccepted: v.boolean(),
    62→  },
    63→  handler: async (ctx, args) => {
    64→    const identity = await ctx.auth.getUserIdentity();
    65→    if (!identity) {
    66→      throw new Error("User not authenticated");
    67→    }
    68→
    69→    // Check if configuration already exists
    70→    const existing = await ctx.db
    71→      .query("gistConfigurations")
    72→      .withIndex("by_user_id", (q) => q.eq("userId", identity.subject))
    73→      .first();
    74→
    75→    const now = Date.now();
    76→
    77→    // Generate favicon URL from storage ID if provided
    78→    let faviconUrl: string | undefined = undefined;
    79→    if (args.faviconStorageId) {
    80→      faviconUrl = (await ctx.storage.getUrl(args.faviconStorageId)) ?? undefined;
    81→    }
    82→
    83→    if (existing) {
    84→      // Update existing configuration
    85→      await ctx.db.patch(existing._id, {
    86→        publicationName: args.publicationName,
    87→        category: args.category,
    88→        ingestionMethod: args.ingestionMethod,
    89→        wordpressUrl: args.wordpressUrl,
    90→        rssFeeds: args.rssFeeds,
    91→        faviconStorageId: args.faviconStorageId,
    92→        faviconUrl: faviconUrl,
    93→        termsAccepted: args.termsAccepted,
    94→        termsAcceptedAt: args.termsAccepted ? now : existing.termsAcceptedAt,
    95→        updatedAt: now,
    96→      });
    97→
    98→      return { success: true, configId: existing._id };
    99→    } else {
   100→      // Create new configuration
   101→      const configId = await ctx.db.insert("gistConfigurations", {
   102→        userId: identity.subject,
   103→        publicationName: args.publicationName,
   104→        category: args.category,
   105→        ingestionMethod: args.ingestionMethod,
   106→        wordpressUrl: args.wordpressUrl,
   107→        rssFeeds: args.rssFeeds,
   108→        faviconStorageId: args.faviconStorageId,
   109→        faviconUrl: faviconUrl,
   110→        termsAccepted: args.termsAccepted,
   111→        termsAcceptedAt: args.termsAccepted ? now : undefined,
   112→        createdAt: now,
   113→        updatedAt: now,
   114→      });
   115→
   116→      return { success: true, configId };
   117→    }
   118→  },
   119→});
   120→

content.text:
Perfect! Now let me create a summary report:

## Implementation Complete: Widget Preview Flow

### Summary

Successfully implemented a comprehensive widget preview flow that allows unauthenticated users to experience the platform before signing up. The system enables users to:

1. **Enter API Key** - Permissive validation (any input accepted)
2. **Select Widget Type** - Choose from 3 widget types (floating, rufus, womensWorld)
3. **Configure Widget** - Customize colors/gradients, dimensions, placement, and behavior
4. **Preview in Demo** - See widget in full-page demo site with CTA to sign up
5. **Automatic Conversion** - Preview configuration converts to user configuration upon sign-up

### Key Features Implemented

✅ **Database Schema**
- `previewConfigurations` table with 24-hour TTL
- `previewToUserMapping` table for conversion tracking
- Proper indexes for efficient querying

✅ **Session Management**
- UUID-based session ID generation
- localStorage persistence across page refreshes
- Automatic cleanup on conversion

✅ **Preview Flow Pages**
- API key entry page (`/preview`)
- Widget type selection (`/preview/select-widget`)
- Configuration page with live preview (`/preview/configure`)
- Full-page demo site (`/preview/demo`)

✅ **Custom Components**
- `ColorGradientPicker` - Solid colors & gradient support with live preview
- `PreviewFlowStepper` - Multi-step progress indicator (4 steps)
- `PreviewWidgetRenderer` - Renders all 3 widget types with configuration

✅ **Route Protection**
- All `/preview/*` routes are public (no authentication required)
- Updated `proxy.ts` middleware configuration

✅ **Automatic Conversion**
- `usePreviewConversion` hook integrated into app
- Converts preview to user configuration on sign-up
- Cleans up preview session after conversion

✅ **UI Components**
- Installed: progress, alert, skeleton from shadcn/ui
- Existing: button, card, input, label, tabs, slider, radio-group

### Files Changed

**New Files (12 files, 1562 lines)**:
- `app/preview/page.tsx` - API key entry (136 lines)
- `app/preview/select-widget/page.tsx` - Widget type selection (188 lines)
- `app/preview/configure/page.tsx` - Configuration with live preview (247 lines)
- `app/preview/demo/page.tsx` - Full-page demo site (135 lines)
- `components/ColorGradientPicker.tsx` - Color/gradient picker (162 lines)
- `components/PreviewFlowStepper.tsx` - Progress stepper (79 lines)

/**
 * Generated data model types.
 *
 * THIS CODE IS AUTOMATICALLY GENERATED.
 *
 * To regenerate, run `npx convex dev`.
 * @module
 */

import type {
  DataModelFromSchemaDefinition,
  DocumentByName,
  TableNamesInDataModel,
  SystemTableNames,
} from "convex/server";
import type { GenericId } from "convex/values";
import schema from "../schema.js";

/**
 * The names of all of your Convex tables.
 */
export type TableNames = TableNamesInDataModel<DataModel>;

/**
 * The type of a document stored in Convex.
 *
 * @typeParam TableName - A string literal type of the table name (like "users").
 */
export type Doc<TableName extends TableNames> = DocumentByName<
  DataModel,
  TableName
>;

/**
 * An identifier for a document in Convex.
 *
 * Convex documents are uniquely identified by their `Id`, which is accessible
 * on the `_id` field. To learn more, see [Document IDs](https://docs.convex.dev/using/document-ids).
 *
 * Documents can be loaded using `db.get(id)` in query and mutation functions.
 *
 * IDs are just strings at runtime, but this type can be used to distinguish them from other
 * strings when type checking.
 *
 * @typeParam TableName - A string literal type of the table name (like "users").
 */
export type Id<TableName extends TableNames | SystemTableNames> =
  GenericId<TableName>;

/**
 * A type describing your Convex data model.
 *
 * This type includes information about what tables you have, the type of
 * documents stored in those tables, and the indexes defined on them.
 *
 * This type is used to parameterize methods like `queryGeneric` and
 * `mutationGeneric` to make them type-safe.
 */
export type DataModel = DataModelFromSchemaDefinition<typeof schema>;
